questions.text: Reading time is best used to start planning answers in your head rather than reading questions carefully.
questions.explanation: Use reading time to read each question thoroughly and highlight key parts. Misreading questions is a major cause of lost marks—students often provide inaccurate responses that don't address what's actually being asked.
questions.studyTip: Highlight key words during reading time. Misread = wrong answer.

questions.text: Highlighting key parts of each question during reading time helps you address exactly what's being asked.
questions.explanation: Effective reading identifies what the question requires before you start writing. Many students lose marks by answering a different question than the one asked.
questions.studyTip: Circle command words and constraints before you write anything.

questions.text: When asked to 'prepare' a general ledger, you must balance and close appropriate accounts.
questions.explanation: 'Prepare' means record entries only. 'Complete' means balance and close appropriate accounts. These are different tasks with different requirements.
questions.studyTip: Prepare = record entries. Complete = balance and close.

questions.text: The command word 'complete' for a general ledger requires you to balance and close appropriate accounts.
questions.explanation: When asked to complete a ledger, you must balance accounts that continue and close expense/revenue accounts to Profit and Loss Summary. Missing this loses easy marks.
questions.studyTip: See 'complete'? Don't forget totals, balances, and closing entries.

concepts.title: Cover all areas of study design

questions.text: Focusing revision on frequently examined topics is the best exam strategy since they're most likely to appear.
questions.explanation: All areas of the Study Design are eligible for assessment. Students who skip topics often miss questions intermittently throughout the exam, not because of time pressure but knowledge gaps.
questions.studyTip: No topic is safe to skip. The exam covers the whole Study Design.

questions.text: Students who miss questions throughout the exam usually have knowledge gaps rather than time management issues.
questions.explanation: Most students complete the exam within allocated time. Intermittent blank answers indicate unfamiliar topics rather than running out of time.
questions.studyTip: Patchy revision = patchy marks. Cover everything.

questions.text: Using shortened account names like 'Accum Dep' instead of 'Accumulated Depreciation of Vehicle' is fine to save time.
questions.explanation: Full, correct account names are required. 'Accumulated Depreciation' without specifying the asset, or missing 'of Van' from cross-references, loses marks.
questions.studyTip: Full names every time: Accumulated Depreciation OF [Asset].

questions.text: Cross-references in ledger accounts must include the specific asset name, like 'Accumulated Depreciation of Delivery Van'.
questions.explanation: Incomplete cross-references such as just 'Accumulated Depreciation' show lack of attention to detail. Assessors require precise account titles.
questions.studyTip: If the asset has a name, put it in the cross-reference.

questions.text: The date column in General Journal entries is optional since the question provides the date information anyway.
questions.explanation: Dates are marked separately. Many students miss a free mark by not including the date when it's clearly required. Read the question—dates matter.
questions.studyTip: Date column exists for a reason. Fill it in.

questions.text: Including the correct date in General Journal entries can earn marks even if other parts have errors.
questions.explanation: Marks are awarded for each correct element. A correct date is a mark you can earn just by reading the question carefully.
questions.studyTip: Free marks exist. Dates are one of them.

questions.text: For discussion questions worth 5-6 marks, briefly mentioning several points is better than discussing fewer points in depth.
questions.explanation: High-mark discussion questions require detailed analysis with examples, justification, and consideration of multiple perspectives. Brief mentions score 1-2 marks at best.
questions.studyTip: 5-6 mark question = detailed discussion, not a list of mentions.

questions.text: Discussion questions require you to consider multiple perspectives and provide detailed justification with examples.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses draw on information provided, link points logically, use correct terminology, and justify conclusions. Simply restating the question scores poorly.
questions.studyTip: Discuss means: pros, cons, evidence, and a justified conclusion.

questions.text: If you know the account affected, the side of the ledger to record on is just a formatting choice.
questions.explanation: Recording entries on the wrong side is a fundamental error that loses all marks for that entry. Debits go on the left, credits on the right—this is not optional.
questions.studyTip: Wrong side = wrong entry. Debits left, credits right. Always.

questions.text: Reversing debit and credit entries in ledger accounts results in complete loss of marks for those entries.
questions.explanation: Entry reversals indicate a lack of understanding of double-entry principles. Even if amounts are correct, reversed entries earn zero marks.
questions.studyTip: Check every entry: Is this increasing or decreasing this account type?

questions.text: Using 'Capital Contribution' as a cross-reference for a capital injection made by bank transfer is correct.
questions.explanation: The cross-reference must be 'Bank' because that's the other account affected. 'Capital Contribution' describes the transaction but isn't an account name.
questions.studyTip: Cross-reference = the OTHER account affected, not a description.

questions.text: Cross-references must name the actual ledger account affected, not describe the type of transaction.
questions.explanation: If cash came from the bank, the cross-reference is Bank. If you transferred from Drawings, the cross-reference is Drawings. Match the actual account.
questions.studyTip: Ask: What account is on the other side of this entry?

questions.text: Wages Expense should be balanced with a carried forward balance like asset accounts.
questions.explanation: Expense accounts are closed to Profit and Loss Summary, not balanced. They need to be reset to zero for the next period.
questions.studyTip: Expenses close to P&L Summary. Assets get carried forward balances.

questions.text: Revenue and expense accounts must be closed to Profit and Loss Summary, not carried forward.
questions.explanation: The period assumption requires clearing revenue and expenses each period. Closing entries transfer these balances to Profit and Loss Summary.
questions.studyTip: Revenue/expense accounts reset to zero each period via P&L Summary.

questions.text: Totals at the bottom of balanced ledger accounts are optional formatting that doesn't affect marks.
questions.explanation: When asked to complete a ledger account, totals are required. Missing totals loses marks even if all entries are correct.
questions.studyTip: No totals = incomplete ledger. Add them.

questions.text: Completed ledger accounts require totals on both sides that balance.
questions.explanation: Totals demonstrate that the account balances correctly. This is part of completing a ledger account properly.
questions.studyTip: Both columns should total to the same amount.

questions.text: If a question lists multiple transactions, missing one still allows full marks for the others.
questions.explanation: Each transaction typically has marks allocated. Missing entries means missing marks. Read the question to ensure all transactions are recorded.
questions.studyTip: Tick off each transaction as you record it. Miss none.

questions.text: Failure to record all entries stipulated in the question results in lost marks.
questions.explanation: Questions specify which transactions to record. Marks are allocated per entry—unrecorded transactions are lost marks.
questions.studyTip: Count the transactions. Count your entries. Do they match?

questions.text: In ledger accounts, the date column can be left blank if the dates are given elsewhere in the question.
questions.explanation: Marks are specifically awarded for using correct dates in all ledgers. Missing dates is a common error that costs easy marks.
questions.studyTip: Dates in ledgers = marks. Fill in every date.

questions.text: Correct dates in ledger accounts are marked separately and can earn marks even if other elements have errors.
questions.explanation: Students should ensure dates are included for every entry. This is a specific marking criterion.
questions.studyTip: Date every entry. It's marked.

questions.text: Writing 'invoice' is sufficient when identifying the source document for a credit purchase of inventory.
questions.explanation: You must specify 'purchase invoice'. A sales invoice is different—it's issued when you sell on credit. Simply writing 'invoice' is not specific enough.
questions.studyTip: Purchase invoice = you're buying. Sales invoice = you're selling.

questions.text: A credit purchase of inventory is verified by a purchase invoice, while a credit sale requires a sales invoice.
questions.explanation: These are different documents with different purposes. Distinguishing them correctly demonstrates understanding of the accounting system.
questions.studyTip: Know which document belongs to which transaction type.

questions.text: A 'cheque' is an acceptable answer when identifying the source document for a cash payment.
questions.explanation: The source document is a 'cheque butt' or 'EFT receipt', not a cheque. The cheque goes to the recipient—you keep the butt as your record.
questions.studyTip: Cheque butt stays with you. That's your source document.

questions.text: A cash payment to accounts payable is verified by a cheque butt or EFT receipt, not by the cheque itself.
questions.explanation: Source documents are the records YOU keep. The cheque goes to the payee; the cheque butt is your retained record of the transaction.
questions.studyTip: Source document = what stays in YOUR records.

questions.text: Multiple transactions from separate source documents can be combined into one General Journal entry for efficiency.
questions.explanation: Each source document requires a separate General Journal entry. Combining entries with different source documents is incorrect.
questions.studyTip: Separate source documents = separate journal entries.

questions.text: Each source document provided requires its own separate General Journal entry.
questions.explanation: A source document is required for each General Journal entry. Multiple source documents mean multiple entries.
questions.studyTip: Count source documents. That's how many entries you need.

questions.text: Recording a sales return as a purchase return is acceptable since both involve inventory coming back.
questions.explanation: Sales returns and purchase returns are completely different transactions with different journal entries. Mixing them up shows fundamental misunderstanding.
questions.studyTip: Customer returns goods = sales return. You return goods = purchase return.

questions.text: Correctly identifying the nature of a transaction from source documents requires understanding different document types.
questions.explanation: Whether it's a sales return, purchase return, or other transaction changes the entire journal entry. Read source documents carefully.
questions.studyTip: Identify the transaction type FIRST, then write the entry.

questions.text: Recording the payment of advertising is the same as recording the balance day adjustment for advertising.
questions.explanation: A payment is a cash transaction. An adjustment allocates prepaid or accrued amounts between periods. These are different entries with different purposes.
questions.studyTip: Payment = cash changes hands. Adjustment = allocating between periods.

questions.text: Balance day adjustments allocate amounts between periods, while payments record when cash changes hands.
questions.explanation: Prepaid Advertising becomes Advertising Expense through an adjustment, not a payment. Know the difference.
questions.studyTip: Adjustments move amounts between asset/liability and expense/revenue accounts.

questions.text: When there's an opening balance in Allowance for Doubtful Debts, you calculate the new allowance without considering it.
questions.explanation: You must consider the opening balance. If the allowance needs to be higher, you increase it; if it needs to be lower, you decrease it. The adjustment brings it to the required level.
questions.studyTip: Opening balance matters. Calculate the adjustment needed, not the total.

questions.text: Be prepared to complete one stage of the bad debts process rather than always doing all stages in one question.
questions.explanation: Questions may ask for just the adjustment, just the write-off, or both. Don't assume you'll always complete the full process.
questions.studyTip: Read exactly what's asked. Bad debts can be tested in parts.

questions.text: Inventory write-down and inventory loss are interchangeable terms for the same accounting treatment.
questions.explanation: Inventory write-down reduces inventory to NRV when value falls. Inventory loss records inventory that is missing, stolen, or destroyed. Different causes, different accounts.
questions.studyTip: Write-down = value dropped. Loss = inventory gone.

questions.text: Recording an inventory write-down as an inventory loss is a common error that shows confusion about different causes.
questions.explanation: Write-downs address reduced value; losses address missing inventory. Using the wrong account demonstrates misunderstanding.
questions.studyTip: Check: Is the inventory still there but worth less? That's a write-down.

questions.text: When explaining a balance day adjustment, identifying the accounting assumption is enough for full marks.
questions.explanation: You need to: (1) identify the adjustment, (2) refer to the accounting assumption, AND (3) explain the treatment in context. All three elements are required.
questions.studyTip: Three parts: What adjustment? Which assumption? Why is it needed?

questions.text: Explaining balance day adjustment treatment requires identifying the assumption AND explaining how it applies to the specific situation.
questions.explanation: Naming 'accrual basis' isn't enough. Explain how that assumption requires this specific adjustment in this specific case.
questions.studyTip: Don't just name the assumption. Apply it to the scenario.

questions.text: Using everyday language instead of accounting terminology is fine if the meaning is clear.
questions.explanation: Terminology is a significant component of the Study Design. Use correct accounting terms, especially those from the Study Design, to demonstrate understanding.
questions.studyTip: Everyday language = vague marks. Use accounting terms.

questions.text: Theory questions require you to support responses with terminology from the Study Design.
questions.explanation: Correct terminology demonstrates understanding. Vague language suggests uncertainty even if the underlying idea is correct.
questions.studyTip: Learn the Study Design glossary. Use those exact terms.

questions.text: Accounting assumptions and qualitative characteristics can be used interchangeably when explaining adjustments.
questions.explanation: These are different concepts. Assumptions (like accrual basis) underpin how we record. Qualitative characteristics (like faithful representation) describe what makes information useful.
questions.studyTip: Assumptions = how we record. Characteristics = what makes info useful.

questions.text: Referring to an accounting assumption when asked about qualitative characteristics results in lost marks.
questions.explanation: If the question asks for a qualitative characteristic, providing an assumption doesn't answer the question. Know the difference.
questions.studyTip: Question says 'qualitative characteristic'? That's NOT going concern or accrual basis.

questions.text: When applying Faithful Representation to balance day adjustments, focus on 'free from error' and 'neutral'.
questions.explanation: For balance day adjustments, focus on faithful representation of real-world economic events. The adjustment ensures the reports represent what actually occurred.
questions.studyTip: Focus on: Does this represent the real economic event accurately?

questions.text: Balance day adjustments ensure reports faithfully represent real-world economic events that have occurred.
questions.explanation: The Allowance for Doubtful Debts faithfully represents that not all receivables will be collected. This is about showing economic reality.
questions.studyTip: Faithful Representation = showing what's really happening economically.

questions.text: Carrying value is a rarely tested concept that doesn't require detailed understanding.
questions.explanation: Only 18% of students achieved full marks when asked about carrying value. Many couldn't identify it from a Balance Sheet extract. This concept needs more attention.
questions.studyTip: Carrying value = Cost − Accumulated Depreciation. Know what it represents.

questions.text: You should be able to both calculate carrying value AND explain what the figure represents.
questions.explanation: Carrying value represents the cost yet to be consumed plus residual value. Being able to explain this, not just calculate it, is tested.
questions.studyTip: Carrying value = unexpired cost of the asset.

questions.text: Saying a financial indicator 'increased' or 'decreased' is sufficient when describing changes.
questions.explanation: Use correct terminology for each indicator. For liquidity ratios, say 'improved' or 'deteriorated'. For turnover, say 'faster' or 'slower'. Be specific.
questions.studyTip: Each indicator has its own language. Learn it.

questions.text: Describing changes in financial indicators requires specific terminology appropriate to each indicator.
questions.explanation: Inventory turnover gets faster or slower. Return on investment improves or deteriorates. Using generic 'increased/decreased' suggests surface-level understanding.
questions.studyTip: Turnover = faster/slower. Ratios = improved/deteriorated.

questions.text: Minor formatting errors in Budgeted Income Statements don't affect marks if the numbers are correct.
questions.explanation: Format is specifically marked. Incorrect formatting, missing headings, or wrong structure loses marks even with correct calculations.
questions.studyTip: Format matters. Use the standard Income Statement structure.

questions.text: Marks are specifically awarded for correct formatting in Budgeted Income Statements.
questions.explanation: Structure, headings, and layout are assessed. Know the standard format and apply it correctly.
questions.studyTip: Practise the format until it's automatic.

questions.text: To find Cost of Sales from Sales when mark-up is 100%, simply halve the Sales figure.
questions.explanation: 100% mark-up means you add the full cost again. So Sales = 2 × Cost. Therefore Cost = Sales ÷ 2. Many students get this calculation wrong.
questions.studyTip: Mark-up 100%: Cost × 2 = Sales. So Cost = Sales ÷ 2.

questions.text: Mark-up percentage is calculated on the selling price, not the cost price.
questions.explanation: Mark-up is calculated ON COST, not on selling price. Margin is on selling price. Confusing these causes calculation errors.
questions.studyTip: Mark-up = on cost. Margin = on selling price. Don't confuse them.

questions.text: Depreciation for a new asset should be calculated for the full year regardless of purchase date.
questions.explanation: If an asset is only owned for part of the year, depreciate for that portion only. A vehicle bought 1 March gets 4/12 of annual depreciation for a June year-end.
questions.studyTip: Count the months of ownership. Apportion accordingly.

questions.text: Assets acquired part-way through the year require pro-rata depreciation calculation.
questions.explanation: Only depreciate for the period of ownership. This is a common error in budgeted reports.
questions.studyTip: New asset in March, June year-end = 4 months' depreciation.

concepts.title: Budget use for planning and control

questions.text: Budgets are mainly useful for reviewing what happened in the past.
questions.explanation: Budgets are planning and control tools used DURING the period—to set goals, assess performance, motivate staff, and control expenses. Not primarily for past review.
questions.studyTip: Budgets look forward. They guide the current period.

questions.text: Budgeted reports are used during the period to set targets, assess performance, and control expenses.
questions.explanation: Planning (setting goals) and control (monitoring and correcting) are the key functions of budgets. Explain both when discussing budget use.
questions.studyTip: Two functions: Planning (set targets) and Control (monitor and correct).

questions.text: When describing the effect of a sales return on the Income Statement, just saying 'it decreases profit' is sufficient.
questions.explanation: You must identify the impact on EACH component: decrease in Net Sales AND decrease in Cost of Sales, leading to decreased Gross Profit. Be specific.
questions.studyTip: Track through the report: Sales → COGS → Gross Profit → Net Profit.

questions.text: Impact on report questions require you to describe the effect on each component affected, not just the final result.
questions.explanation: A sales return decreases Net Sales by the selling price AND decreases Cost of Sales by the cost price. Show the full trail of effects.
questions.studyTip: Show every line affected and by how much.

questions.text: Cash Flow Cover is a profitability indicator since it involves cash from operations.
questions.explanation: Cash Flow Cover is a LIQUIDITY indicator. It shows whether the business generates enough cash from operations to meet short-term debts as they fall due.
questions.studyTip: Cash Flow Cover = liquidity, not profitability.

questions.text: Cash Flow Cover indicates whether a business can generate enough cash from operations to meet short-term obligations.
questions.explanation: It compares net cash from operating activities to current liabilities. A business should rely on operations for cash, not selling assets or borrowing.
questions.studyTip: Good cash flow cover = meeting debts from operations, not loans or asset sales.

questions.text: Return on investment and return on assets always move in the same direction.
questions.explanation: These can differ significantly due to debt ratio. A business using borrowed funds can have high return on investment while return on assets matches industry average.
questions.studyTip: Debt amplifies owner's return. That's leverage.

questions.text: Understanding relationships between financial indicators helps explain apparent anomalies in business performance.
questions.explanation: High return on investment with average return on assets often indicates use of borrowed funds (leverage). Study these relationships throughout the year, not just at revision time.
questions.studyTip: Indicators connect. High leverage → owner return exceeds asset return.

questions.text: Improving profitability will automatically improve liquidity.
questions.explanation: Profitability and liquidity are different. A business can be profitable but have poor liquidity if profit is tied up in receivables or inventory. Address each separately.
questions.studyTip: Profit ≠ cash. A profitable business can still fail on liquidity.

questions.text: Strategies to improve liquidity may differ from strategies to improve profitability.
questions.explanation: Increasing mark-up improves profitability but may not help liquidity if sales are on credit. Target the right problem with the right solution.
questions.studyTip: Know what each strategy actually improves.

questions.text: Increasing inventory range is a good strategy to improve inventory turnover.
questions.explanation: More inventory with same sales means SLOWER turnover, not faster. To improve (speed up) turnover: reduce inventory levels, sell faster, or remove slow-moving lines.
questions.studyTip: Faster turnover = less inventory OR more sales. Not more inventory.

questions.text: To improve inventory turnover, either reduce inventory levels or increase sales velocity.
questions.explanation: Inventory turnover improves (gets faster) when you hold less inventory or sell more. Consider just-in-time ordering, removing obsolete lines, or increasing sales.
questions.studyTip: Turnover = Cost of Sales ÷ Average Inventory. Change one or both.

questions.text: Stating 'unable to meet short-term debts as they fall due' is a complete description of a liquidity problem.
questions.explanation: This is vague. Describe SPECIFIC consequences: unable to pay suppliers (losing supply), late wages (staff leaving), ATO penalties, forced asset sales, or bankruptcy.
questions.studyTip: Be specific: WHO can't you pay? WHAT happens then?

questions.text: Liquidity problem descriptions should identify specific consequences, like supplier relationships or staff retention issues.
questions.explanation: Higher-scoring responses describe concrete effects: can't pay suppliers → lose stock supply → can't make sales. Chain the consequences.
questions.studyTip: Think through the domino effect. What breaks first? Then what?

questions.text: Memorising model answers for discussion questions is an effective exam strategy.
questions.explanation: Discussion questions require you to respond to specific source material provided. Pre-learned responses rarely address the actual question and score poorly.
questions.studyTip: Read the scenario. Respond to THAT scenario, not a memorised one.

questions.text: Discussion questions require specific engagement with the source material provided, not generic responses.
questions.explanation: Each discussion question has unique context. Your response must draw on the specific information given, not repeat a prepared answer.
questions.studyTip: Quote from the scenario. Show you've read it.

questions.text: In discussion questions, taking a strong position on one side shows confidence and scores well.
questions.explanation: Discussion requires considering BOTH sides. Simply arguing one position without acknowledging counter-arguments scores lower. Present pros, cons, then conclude.
questions.studyTip: Discuss = both sides. Argue = one side. Know which you're asked for.

questions.text: High-scoring discussion responses present arguments on both sides before reaching a justified conclusion.
questions.explanation: Show you understand the complexity. Present the case for, the case against, weigh them up, then make a reasoned recommendation.
questions.studyTip: Structure: Point for, point against, weigh up, conclude.

questions.text: Starting your answer by restating the question information shows you've read it carefully.
questions.explanation: Repeating question content wastes time and adds no marks. Assessors know what the question said. Use your words to ANALYSE, not REPEAT.
questions.studyTip: Don't parrot the question back. Analyse it.

questions.text: Simply restating information provided in the question demonstrates lack of depth and earns few marks.
questions.explanation: Discussion questions test your ability to apply understanding to new situations. Repeating the scenario shows nothing about your knowledge.
questions.studyTip: Add value. What does the info MEAN? What are the IMPLICATIONS?

questions.text: Ethical considerations and financial considerations should be discussed separately without linking them.
questions.explanation: Higher-scoring responses show how ethical and financial factors connect. An ethical choice might harm finances; a financial choice might raise ethical issues. Explore the tension.
questions.studyTip: Best responses show trade-offs between ethics and finances.

questions.text: Strong discussion responses connect ethical choices to their financial implications and vice versa.
questions.explanation: Keeping oversupplied inventory is financially beneficial but ethically questionable. Higher scores come from showing how these factors interact and influence decisions.
questions.studyTip: Ask: What's the ethical cost of the financial benefit?

questions.text: Ethical questions usually involve the same themes, so learning one scenario thoroughly is enough.
questions.explanation: Ethical scenarios cannot be predicted year to year. Be prepared for a range: oversupply issues, environmental choices, staff treatment, customer relationships, supplier dealings.
questions.studyTip: Practise applying ethical thinking to DIFFERENT scenarios.

questions.text: Being prepared for discussion questions means having experience with many different ethical scenarios.
questions.explanation: Each year brings new contexts. Practise thinking through ethical implications across various business situations throughout the year.
questions.studyTip: The skill is ethical analysis, not knowing one scenario.

questions.text: When calculating credit sales from an Accounts Receivable ledger, use the total including GST.
questions.explanation: Credit Sales (revenue) excludes GST. If the ledger shows Sales/GST Clearing, you need to remove GST to find actual credit sales revenue.
questions.studyTip: Revenue excludes GST. Extract it from combined amounts.

questions.text: Cost prices and expense amounts in calculations should exclude GST for GST-registered businesses.
questions.explanation: GST is not a cost for registered businesses—it's collected and passed on. Use GST-exclusive figures for costs and expenses.
questions.studyTip: GST-registered? Work with GST-exclusive amounts.

questions.text: To find the bad debts expense, calculate the required allowance percentage without considering any opening balance.
questions.explanation: The adjustment depends on what allowance you NEED versus what you already HAVE. If opening balance is $3,000 and you need $12,000, the adjustment is $9,000.
questions.studyTip: Adjustment = Required balance − Opening balance.

questions.text: The allowance adjustment must account for any existing opening balance and any write-offs during the period.
questions.explanation: Common error: forgetting to reset the allowance after a write-off. If allowance was $3,000, you wrote off $3,600, you're now $600 negative before calculating the new requirement.
questions.studyTip: Track: Opening → Write-offs → What's left → What's needed → Adjustment.

questions.text: If rent changes from 1 January, use the new rate for the entire year in a June-ending budget.
questions.explanation: Apportion: 6 months at old rate (July-December) plus 6 months at new rate (January-June). Part-year changes need careful allocation.
questions.studyTip: Count months at each rate. Add them.

questions.text: Budget calculations must apportion expenses when rates change part-way through the budget period.
questions.explanation: A rent increase from 1 January affects only half the year for a June year-end. Calculate each portion separately.
questions.studyTip: Change date matters. Split the calculation.

questions.text: Using 'GST Clearing' as the cross-reference for a sale recorded in Unearned Sales Revenue is correct.
questions.explanation: When recording the sales portion, cross-reference is 'Sales', not 'GST Clearing'. GST Clearing is only for the GST component, not the sales revenue.
questions.studyTip: Sales amount → Sales. GST amount → GST Clearing. Keep them separate.

questions.text: Sales recorded in Unearned Sales Revenue should use 'Sales' as the cross-reference, not 'GST Clearing'.
questions.explanation: The revenue portion goes to Sales. The GST portion goes to GST Clearing. Using GST Clearing for the revenue portion is a common error.
questions.studyTip: Revenue and GST are separate entries with separate cross-references.

questions.text: Modelling questions follow a standard format, so learning one approach covers all variations.
questions.explanation: Modelling questions have developed in complexity since their introduction. They now require flexible thinking, not formulaic responses.
questions.studyTip: Modelling questions evolve. Stay adaptable.

questions.text: Modelling questions test your ability to adjust figures based on given assumptions and scenarios.
questions.explanation: These questions require you to project or adjust figures based on new information. Students generally score well here—maintain this strength.
questions.studyTip: Read the assumptions carefully. Apply each one systematically.

questions.text: Cash versus profit questions always follow a predictable format you can prepare specific answers for.
questions.explanation: These questions appear in different styles. The 2023 exam took a 'different approach to the traditional style' and many students struggled. Be ready for variations.
questions.studyTip: Understand the CONCEPT of cash vs profit. Don't just memorise formats.

questions.text: You must be prepared for cash versus profit questions asked in different styles from previous exams.
questions.explanation: This topic appears regularly but in varying formats. Understand why cash and profit differ—credit sales, depreciation, balance day adjustments—and apply that understanding.
questions.studyTip: Why does profit ≠ cash? Understand that, and any question style is manageable.

questions.text: Different depreciation methods give different total depreciation over an asset's life.
questions.explanation: Total depreciation is the same regardless of method—it's Cost minus Residual Value. What differs is how much is allocated to each year. Methods affect timing, not total.
questions.studyTip: Same total over the life. Different amounts each year.

questions.text: Straight-line and reducing balance methods allocate the same total depreciation, just distributed differently over the asset's life.
questions.explanation: Both methods depreciate (Cost − Residual Value) in total. Reducing balance front-loads; straight-line spreads evenly. Match method to revenue-earning pattern.
questions.studyTip: Choose method based on when the asset generates most revenue.

questions.text: Understanding Cash Flow Statement Operating Activities requires only knowing which items go there.
questions.explanation: Questions require deeper understanding: explaining why items are there, calculating figures from other information, understanding the relationship with profit.
questions.studyTip: Don't just list operating items. Understand where the figures come from.

questions.text: Be prepared for questions requiring you to calculate operating activities figures from other financial information.
questions.explanation: Rote-learned formats aren't enough. You may need to derive figures or explain relationships rather than simply place items in categories.
questions.studyTip: Practise deriving figures, not just categorising them.

questions.text: Constraints in questions like 'do not refer to relevance' are suggestions rather than requirements.
questions.explanation: Constraints are REQUIREMENTS. If a question says don't refer to relevance and you do, your response doesn't address the question asked.
questions.studyTip: Constraints aren't optional. Violating them = not answering the question.

questions.text: Questions with constraints require you to demonstrate knowledge within specific limitations.
questions.explanation: Constraints test whether you can identify ALTERNATIVE correct answers. If relevance is excluded, you must identify a different qualitative characteristic.
questions.studyTip: Read constraints first. They shape your entire answer.
